activity.instructions: Talk about what is important in a job

item.audiotext: So how important are promotion prospects to you?
item.choice: My main priority is job satisfaction. I need to feel happy in my job.
I couldn't do absolutely without promotion prospects. This is really important.
This isn't an essential priority.

item.audiotext: And does your working environment affect this?
item.choice: I'm not too bothered about the environment, but supportive colleagues are essential.
I don't care at all about the job satisfaction.
This isn't a major priority when you consider perks.

item.audiotext: How about the boss? Should he or she be supportive too?
item.choice: Yes, I think that is absolutely vital.
She needs to be a priority.
I couldn't do without a boss.
This isn't a major priority for me. I am quite flexible about the hours.
The essential thing for me is to be flexible.
I couldn't do without working hours.
The essential thing for me is that I am not underpaid for what I do.
This salary is absolutely vital.
This isn't a major priority. A good salary is essential.
I'm not really concerned about my pension.
I couldn't do without getting old.
Getting a pension is not concerning me.

item.audiotext: Do you think professional development is an issue?
item.choice: I couldn't do without some kind of personal and professional development in my job. This is essential.
I could do without a professional development issue.
Professional and personal development is essentially for me.

activity.instructions: A friend has sent you an email asking for advice. Write a reply.
activity.email: Hi Martin, # My friend Tara and I are thinking of starting up a small flower business together and wondered if you had any advice. Thanks.

item.choice: First of all, you need to be sure of your business plan.
First of all, can you roll up your sleeves?
Firstly, do you strike the right balance?
Make sure you've done some thorough market research, and perhaps hire a consultant to help you crunch the numbers.
You need to have a product design to make the business work.
If you buy someone out of the business it could be an expensive proposition.
Then look at how you want to divide the business.
You could hold back information.
Then execute the strategy.
Are you going to be 50-50 partners?
Is it a family-owned business?
Do you hire a consultant?
Have you thought about how going into business together could jeopardise your friendship?
There is a start-up phase afterwards.
Have you got an attractive job offer?
Make sure you can communicate directly and honestly with each other, otherwise the business may suffer.
Make sure you can do a contract negotiation.
Be sure this is a life-changing event.
Think about your roles. Who is the strategic 'big thinker'? Who is going to execute the strategy?
Think about holding back information. You might buy someone out of the business.
Think about your roles. Who can roll up their sleeves? Who can think?
And when the going gets tough, make sure you can still laugh about it. Good luck. Let me know how things work out.
Martin
